Second, At that time, the messenger ran quickly to catch him, this is leading with the teaching of the Great Vehicle, which corresponds to the line in the Fire-house chapter, I will carry them out on my robe, on a chair, or on a table.

The second part of leading with the exhortation of no affinity has two parts. The poor son was startled is the first part, which clarifies that there is the affinity for the Lesser Vehicle, the human realm, and the heavenly realm.

The Fire-house Parable above clarifies that there is no affinity. Within it originally has two parts. The first says, This house has only one gate, and it is narrow, clarifying that the Great Vehicle teaching is not useful for them.
Now, this is not leading with this, but only leading with the clarification of no affinity. It originally has two parts:

This one sentence leads with the affinity for the Lesser Vehicle, which is the line The children are young, and the Great Vehicle teaching is not what they expect, so it says startled.

Crying out in resentment and below is the second part about not having a great capacity, which corresponds to the line above not recognizing anything. If I had a Mahayana capacity and went to violate your Mahayana teaching, I could have received the Mahayana teaching and been caught, but since I have none, why would I be caught?

The messengers seized him and below is the second part, called the section on not coming when called again. The above corresponds to the admonition and suitability without capacity. It also has two parts:

The two in the admonitions and teachings being appropriate is the understanding of the two sections of the parable, the emissaries holding him even more tightly is the first, understanding the above contemplation of admonitions and teachings, which is the fire-house saying I will speak to them of fearful matters, the admonitions and teachings of the Great Vehicle are swift, thus it is said to be tight.

The second forcefully dragging him back directly understands the admonitions and teachings being appropriate, which is the fire-house saying as I have contemplated, I will fully inform the children, clarifying that at that time the small capacities did not accord with the Great Vehicle teachings, thus it is said to be forcefully dragging.

The second part, from At that time the impoverished son thought to himself, 'I have committed no crime' and so on, is about not understanding the admonition. It also has two parts, corresponding to the two sections of the parable. The first says, At that time the impoverished son thought to himself, 'I have committed no crime, yet I have been imprisoned and will certainly die.' This first corresponds to the lack of a great capacity, which is the second part of the Fire-house parable that clearly shows the lack of a great capacity, 'They were unwilling to believe and accept it, were not alarmed or afraid, and had no intention of leaving.'
Since I have no great capacity, you are forcefully using admonitions and teachings to pressure me, which may cause me to give rise to slander and cut off the wisdom-life of good roots.

'He became even more frightened, confused, and collapsed on the ground.' This is the second part, which corresponds to the existence of a small capacity, which is the first part of the Fire-house parable about the small capacities of humans and gods, 'Although the father pitied them and used kind words to persuade them, the children were attached to their play and did not listen.'
A small capacity is unable to accept the great teaching, like collapsing on the ground.

The father saw him from afar - below this is the third analogy of abandoning the child, which comprehensively leads to the cessation of teaching in both families. This leads to the urging to cease teaching in the Burning House, saying he might fall and be burned by the fire;
The admonition to cease teaching says he only ran around looking at his father.
It also remotely leads to the passage in the chapter on skillful means, from I immediately had this thought up to I would rather not teach the Dharma and quickly enter nirvana.
In this cessation of teaching, there are also two parts. The first is thinking of wanting to abandon the child, which internally corresponds to wanting to cease teaching;
The second, from the messenger told him below, clarifies the release of the child, which internally corresponds to clearly showing the cessation of teaching.
Moreover, in these two sections, each has two parts.
In the thinking of cessation of teaching, there are two: the first is thinking of wanting to cease teaching, the second, from why is it so below, explains the intention of wanting to cease teaching.
Each of these two sections has two meanings:
First, contemplating the cessation of the transformation, second, first clarifying the existence of the small, and later clarifying the non-existence of the great.
Now, first clarifying the existence of the small, the father saw from afar means that the small capacity is far away from the great teaching, so it is said to be seen from afar.

When the teaching is about to cease the transformation, it is like saying Do not need this person, do not force him to come, the human and heavenly capacities are like the face, the human and heavenly teachings are like cold water, the human and heavenly teachings accord with the capacities, so it is said Sprinkle on the face to make him come to his senses.
Do not speak to him again means there is no great capacity. Because there is no great capacity, do not speak to him again, meaning there is no great capacity.
Why is it so? This is the second, explaining the meaning of the two kinds of desire to cease the transformation above.
It is precisely because there is the small but not the great that the transformation ceases, thus forming two sections:
With a lowly attitude means this is having the small, this explains the above phrase sprinkle water on the face;

Knowing oneself to be difficult to be a son of the wealthy below this explains the absence of the great, this explains the above phrase do not speak to him again; it also says it explains the above phrase do not forcibly bring him back.

This is the same as the passage in the Burning House chapter that exhorts to stop the teaching and transform, saying They will cling to the place of play and may fall down, and the passage that admonishes to stop the teaching and transform, saying They will only run around and play, looking at their father. This is the same as the meaning in the Skillful Means chapter, I would rather not teach the Dharma and quickly enter nirvana.
The second says The poor son was delighted, which clarifies that stopping the teaching and transforming was appropriate, and contains two meanings, therefore he was delighted.

Second, rising from the ground means that when he was previously targeted by the Mahayana teaching, it was like falling to the ground. Now that he is no longer targeted by the Mahayana teaching, it is like rising from the ground.

The teaching of humans and gods is like a poor village, and the rewards of humans and gods within it are like clothing and food. This is the small teaching of humans and gods that accords with the small capacity of humans and gods, therefore he was delighted.

At that time the elder, wishing to lure his son... From here is the fourth section on calling the sons and obtaining them. This corresponds to the fourth and fifth parables in the above fourth section.

Now this fourth section corresponds to the first two parts in the above fourth section, which are the expedient means of the three vehicles and the opportunity seen in the three vehicles. In this parable there are two parts. The first clarifies the father calling his sons, and the second, from having already obtained it, clarifies seeing the sons accepting the call.

In terms of the inner meaning, it first corresponds to the Buddha's expedient means using the teachings of the three vehicles, and later sees the people of the three vehicles able to accept them. In these two parts there are four levels each.

The first, the father calling his sons, has four levels. First, using the outer parable to speak, first seeking out a suitable person to send; second, immediately obtaining a suitable person to send; third, speaking with the person to be sent; fourth, the messenger accepting the order and calling out.

Haggard appearances refers to the teachings named according to principle, if using the teachings of the Great Vehicle to expound the principle of the Great Vehicle, it is called radiant appearance, now the teachings of the Two Vehicles cannot expound the principle of the causes and effects of the Great Vehicle, thus speaking of haggardness.

The reason it says first taking the wages is the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising outside the three realms. And ordered his son and gathered his relatives - below this is the second gathering of the assembly of witnesses. Internally, it clarifies the Tathagata emitting light and shaking the earth to gather those with affinities, which is the meaning of at that time, the World-Honored One was surrounded by the fourfold assembly. The manifested Buddhas are like relatives, the stupa of the Buddha Prabhutaratna is like a king, the bodhisattvas on the tenth ground are like ministers, the bodhisattvas on the ninth ground are like kshatriyas, and the bodhisattvas from the eighth ground and below are like householders.

Then he declared himself - below this is the third narration of the natural relationship between father and son. Internally, it clarifies the meaning of reconciling the past and present, which is the proclamation at the Dharma Flower Assembly today, saying that in the past he already used the Mahayana to transform you, and now he again uses the Mahayana to transform you.
This is truly my son - this is truly the Mahayana child transformed in the past.
In a certain city - the teaching of the twenty myriads of millions of Buddhas is the certain city.

Abandoned me and ran away means that in the past the Buddha used the Great Vehicle to transform, but later sentient beings lost their understanding of the Great Vehicle. Since they lost the secret, there is the meaning of being far from the Buddha, so it is said that they abandoned me and ran away.
Having already lost the great understanding and extensively giving rise to afflictions, they experience the six destinies, so it is said that they suffered for more than fifty years.

His original name was so-and-so, and my name is so-and-so. In the past, in the original city, I worried and searched for him means that since the time of the twenty koá¹­Ä«s of Buddhas, he has always been seeking sentient beings with the capacity for the One Vehicle, so it is said that he searched for him.
Now, the great capacity has finally been activated, in accordance with his original intention, so it is said that he has found him.
This is truly my son means that he is truly the son of the bodhisattvas, and has been receiving the transformation of the Great Vehicle.
I am truly his father means that I am truly the one who has been transforming with the Great Vehicle.

All the wealth and property I now possess - this is the fourth, the actual entrustment of the family business, which corresponds to the Buddha's actual teaching of the Lotus Sutra to the bodhisattvas and bestowing upon them the prediction of Buddhahood.

What I now possess all belongs to you - this entrusts the meaning of revealing the One, and addressing the practitioners of the three vehicles, saying that in the future they will attain the fruit of Buddhahood just like me, and therefore it is said to belong to you.

What has been given out and what has been kept within - this entrusts the meaning of revealing the three, and says that the teachings of the three vehicles and so forth that I have expounded in the past are all for sentient beings to know that they are skillful means, and therefore it is said to be what you know.

At that time, the poor son, hearing these words of his father, was greatly delighted. This is the ninth joy of the son, corresponding to the ninth section of the Burning House in the Lotus Sutra, At that time, the children, each riding in a great carriage, obtained what they had never had before, clarifying the joy of obtaining the carriage. It also remotely corresponds to the ninth section of the Skillful Means Chapter, The bodhisattvas, hearing this teaching, all removed their nets of doubts. The 1,200 arhats will also become buddhas, clarifying that the people of the three vehicles, hearing the teaching of the Lotus Sutra, will receive the prediction of becoming a buddha and therefore rejoice.

I originally had no intention - these four great Å›rÄvakas themselves say that when they saw the great causes and great fruits at the seat of the Great Vehicle in the Great Vehicle Sutra, at that time they had no desire at all;
this brings up their lack of seeking in the past to explain their present spontaneous attainment.

The World-Honored One, the greatly wealthy elder, is precisely the TathÄgata, and we are all like the Buddha's sons. From here below is the second part that corresponds to the parable. In the original text, there were nine parables, and now it also corresponds to the nine parables, but it is abbreviated.

Now, it says, The greatly wealthy elder is precisely the TathÄgata, and we are all like the Buddha's sons. These two sentences correspond to the first parable of the father and son being separated. In the original parable, there were originally four sections: first, the son left the father and went away; second, the father searched for the son but could not find him; third, the son returned and was near the father; fourth, after losing the son, the father's worry and concern deepened.
Moreover, within these four sections, each has two steps. Now, these two sentences completely correspond to the original text.
Now, it says, The greatly wealthy elder is precisely the TathÄgata. This upper sentence corresponds to the second and fourth sections of the original text.
We are all like the Buddha's sons. This lower sentence corresponds to the first and third sections of the original text.

The upper sentence combines the two sections. In the second section on the father not finding the son, there are two steps: first, directly stating that he did not find the son; second, saying that he did not abandon the great work of the family business for the small matter of losing one son.
In the fourth section on the father's increasing worry, there are two steps: first, stating the suffering of losing the son; second, stating the joy of thinking of finding the son.

We are all like the Buddha's sons - this sentence combines the first and third sections. In the first section on the son leaving the father, there are two steps: first, turning one's back on the father and leaving; second, heading towards the country and returning.
In the third section on the son approaching the father, there are two steps: first, the conditions for approaching the father; second, directly stating the approach to the father.
The single sentence The TathÄgata always says we are his sons combines the second section on the father and son seeing each other.
In the above parable, there are two parts: first, stating that the son sees the father; second, the father sees the son.

The son seeing the father has four steps, but now they are all out of order: first, seeing the reason for seeing the father; second, seeing the place of the father; third, seeing the father sitting on a lion's seat clearly shows seeing the father; fourth, giving rise to a mind of fear and avoidance. These four steps are all out of order.
Only the second step, the father seeing the son, is correct.
But in the above seeing the son there are also four steps, and now the first and third steps are out of order, while the second and fourth steps are combined.
The second step says seeing the son and immediately recognizing him, which is the meaning of seeing the son.

It also combines the fourth step, saying I have always been thinking of this son without any way to see him, but he suddenly came on his own, greatly pleasing my wishes, showing that the elder, having seen the son, gives rise to a thought of joy.
Now combining the two steps, it says the TathÄgata always says we are his sons.

In brief, it does not correspond to the first statement At that time, the wealthy elder, on the lion seat which clarifies the place where he saw his son, nor does it correspond to the third statement His mind greatly rejoiced.

World-Honored One, we, because of the three kinds of suffering, experience various torments in birth and death, confused and ignorant, delighting in the lesser teachings. These three sentences correspond to the third part of the above parable, Calling his sons but they would not go.

In the above parable, there were originally three parts: the first was understanding the exhortation and suitability, but there was no response; the second was understanding the warning and suitability, but there was no response; the third was comprehensively understanding the warning and exhortation, and both sides ceased the teaching.
Now, it only corresponds to the first two sections, and does not correspond to the third, which is understanding the cessation of the teaching.
But above, understanding the exhortation and warning, suitability, and lack of response, each has two parts.
Understanding the exhortation has two parts:
The first is understanding the exhortation and teaching, suitability, which has two parts, but they are not corresponding.
The second is clarifying the lack of response, which also has two parts, and now they are corresponding.
There are two parts in the section on leading and admonishing:
First, leading and admonishing with provisional expedients, which has two steps, but they are not combined now;
Second, leading and admonishing with no response, which has two parts, but they are also combined now.
Therefore, the provisional expedients of the two parties are not combined now, only the lack of response of the two parties is combined.
There are two parts in leading and admonishing with no response:
First, clarifying the existence of the small, second, clarifying the absence of the great.
There are two parts in leading and admonishing with no response:
First, clarifying the absence of the great, second, clarifying the existence of the small.
Now, the lack of a great response of the two parties is combined, and the existence of a small response of the two parties is also combined.

In this combination, there are two kinds of extensions. Now it says, We, because of the three sufferings, experience various torments in birth and death. This is the first. First, explaining the reason for the absence of the great intention, it is precisely because of the five turbidities that there is no great response.
The three sufferings refer to the sufferings within the three realms, not to the suffering of suffering, the suffering of change, and the suffering of conditioned existence.
The second is the actual correspondence. Confused and ignorant corresponds to the lack of great capacity in both the admonishment and encouragement sections.

Above, in the encouragement section, it corresponds to the lack of great capacity, saying He cried out in resentment, 'I have not committed any offense. Why are you arresting me?' In the admonishment section, it corresponds to the lack of great capacity, saying At that time, the poor son thought, 'I have not committed any crime, yet I am imprisoned. This is definitely a death sentence.' Now, confused and ignorant simply refers to the lack of the capacity for the Great Vehicle.

Delighting in the lesser teachings corresponds to the presence of the capacity for the lesser in both [the admonishment and encouragement sections]. In the encouragement section, it corresponds to the lesser capacity, saying The poor son was startled. In the admonishment section, it corresponds to the lesser capacity, saying He became even more frightened and fell to the ground in a faint. These both clarify the presence of the capacity for the lesser.
Now, delighting in the lesser teachings simply refers to the presence of the capacity for the lesser, and thus delighting in the lesser teachings.

Today the World-Honored One has us contemplate and remove the filth of conceptual proliferation in all dharmas up to because of diligent effort, we have obtained much corresponds to the fourth section of the parable of calling the children and their response.
In the parable of calling the children above, there are two parts:
First, the elder sends people to call the children; second, from having already obtained them below, it clarifies the children seeing their father and accepting the call.
Now, these two parts are combined. In the elder calling the children above, there were originally four parts, but now only the fourth part is combined.
The first part above states: The elder, wishing to lure his children, first finds someone to send, clarifying the TathÄgata's seeking of skillful means and teachings. Now, this is not combined.

The second states: Secretly sending two people with haggard appearances and no dignity, obtaining someone to send, which clarifies obtaining skillful means and teachings. Now, this is also not combined.
Third, from You may go to him below, the words of the messenger show that the Buddha creates expedient teachings, but this is not appropriate now.

Fourth, the line Then the two messengers immediately sought out the poor son clearly shows the messengers obeying the order to call the son. Internally, it clearly shows the TathÄgata using the teachings of the Three Vehicles to accord with sentient beings, but only this fourth stage is appropriate.

Today the World-Honored One has us contemplate and remove the filth of conceptual proliferation in all dharmas - this directly corresponds to Then the two messengers immediately sought out the poor son.

In seeing the son accept the call, there are also four stages, but now only the third stage is appropriate. First, Having already obtained him refers to the external worldlings who are capable of hearing the teachings, but this is not appropriate now.
Fully presenting the above matter refers to the internal and external worldlings who are capable of receiving the teachings, but this is also not appropriate now.

The fourth section says, The father saw his son and felt pity and wonder, meaning the elder saw his son only had the aspiration for the lesser and the capacity for attaining the fruit of no-more-learning, so he gave rise to a heart of pity and sympathy, which is now inappropriate.

Only the third section is appropriate, saying, At that time the poor son first took his wages and then helped with the cleaning, meaning there was the capacity for seeing the truth and contemplating the practice. Now it says, We diligently applied ourselves in this and attained the price of one day's work in nirvana, and further says, Because of diligent practice, we obtained much, which precisely corresponds to the capacity for practice in the third section above.

However, the World-Honored One first knew that our minds were attached to inferior desires from here up to have no aspiration for this Great Vehicle forms three phrases, corresponding to the fifth section above on the analogy of teaching and making people.

In the above parable, there were originally three parts: the first is the reason for teaching the making, the second is the actual teaching of making, and the third is clarifying that the maker accords with the elder's intention.
Now, these three sections are all complete, but only abbreviated.

First, it combines the first, the reason for teaching the making, which originally had three parts: the first is first clarifying that the elder sees his son, the second says discarding the attire of the noble ones, and the third says accepting the attire of the lowly ones, which is discarding the Dharma body and accepting the response body.
Now, only the first part is combined, and the latter two parts are not combined.
But in the first part, the elder seeing his son originally had three points: the first is saying and on another day to clarify the time of seeing the son, which is not combined now.
The second is saying in the window to clarify the place of seeing the son, which is also not combined now.
Only the third, the actual seeing of the son, is combined.

Above, it is explained that the son was seen with a weak and emaciated body, haggard and filthy, impure, and at that time there was only a small capacity that was unable to be taught the great, so it is said first knowing that we are deeply attached to desires and hindrances down to not distinguishing the division of the treasure store.
The World-Honored One, with the power of skillful means, spoke of the wisdom of the TathÄgata, this is the combination of the second main teaching above.

But the teaching above has four parts, which correspond to the explanation of the three carts in four steps in the parable. Now, the first and fourth are not combined, only the second and third are combined.
The first statement above is all you workers, work diligently and do not slack off, which corresponds to the encouragement to accept the three carts in the burning house, but now it is not combined.

The second statement, Later he said again, 'Hey man, you should always work here and not go elsewhere. I will increase your wages,' corresponds to the above section on showing the three carts. Now this combines the second and also combines the third statement, All the necessary utensils, rice, flour, salt, vinegar, and so on, clarifying that the elder praises the completion of the work, which corresponds to the above praise of the three carts.
The fourth statement above, Take good care of yourself. I am like your father. Do not worry anymore, corresponds to the above assurance of non-falseness, but is not combined now.
Therefore it is said that there are four in the correct teaching of work, not combining the first and fourth, only combining the second and third.

The reason it is said that the World-Honored One, with the power of skillful means, expounds the wisdom of the TathÄgata is that the World-Honored One, with the power of skillful means, expounds the cause of the wisdom of the TathÄgata, taking it as the different fruits of us three vehicle practitioners.

We have gained a day's wages from the Buddha's nirvana as if it were a great gain, and have no aspiration for this Great Vehicle, is equivalent to the third section in the parable of the workers in the teaching, where the workers agree with the elder's terms.
Above, in agreeing with him, there were originally four steps, which correspond to the four steps in the disciples' acceptance and practice above. Now only the fourth step is combined.
First, below When you are working for me, it corresponds to the meaning of their minds were each vigorous and sharp, but now it is not combined.
Second, below From now on, you will be like my own son, it corresponds to the mutual pushing and shoving in the practice of the inner disciples above, but now it is also not combined.

Third, below At that time, although the poor son was delighted by this encounter, it corresponds to the competing to run of seeing the truth, contemplating, cultivating the path, and practicing above, but now it is also not combined.

The fourth says after this, our minds are at ease with each other, and we come and go without difficulty, which corresponds to the above dispute and leave the burning house and attain the fruit of arhatship.
Now, this only corresponds to the fourth stage.
Obtaining nirvana from the Buddha is just the fruit of arhatship from the past, which is considered a great gain as a day's wage;
Therefore, it is like working for a hundred days in a famine and only getting a thousand, but getting a thousand for working one day today, which is considered a great gain for today.

Working for a hundred days in the past and getting a thousand is only equal to working for one day today, which is equivalent to saying that in the past one considered oneself to have gained much, no different from attaining the fruit of arhatship in the past and having various merits and wisdom. Since one's own abilities are not equal to the Buddha's fruit of merit and wisdom today, it is called a day's wage.
We also, because of the TathÄgata's wisdom - the following three sentences correspond to the sixth analogy of entrusting with property.
In the above parable, there were two parts: first, the father's entrustment, and second, the son's acceptance. The father's entrustment had three steps, which are not combined here.
In the son's acceptance, there were also three steps, which are now fully combined.
Now, We also because of the TathÄgata's wisdom combines with the first part above, At that time the poor son immediately accepted the instructions.
For the bodhisattvas, revealing and expounding and below combines with the second step above, Managing the various goods and treasuries.
But have no aspiration for this and below, up to according to what we say, combines with the third step above, But had no intention of taking even a single meal.
But we do not know that we truly are the Buddha's disciples this one sentence combines with the seventh part above, the parable of seeing the son's great aspiration.

The above says After some time, the father knew that his son's mind had gradually become open and at ease, and had accomplished great aspirations, despising his previous mind. There were three parts, but now only the second is combined.ğŸ”½The reason it says We do not know that we are truly the Buddha's disciples is that when we had the capacity for the Great Vehicle, only the TathÄgata knew, but we ourselves did not know.
Bringing up our own ignorance reveals the TathÄgata's knowledge, so it says we do not know that we are truly the Buddha's disciples.
Now we know that the World-Honored One is not stingy with the wisdom of the Buddha. The two phrases below this combine with the eighth parable of entrusting the family business above.
In the original parable, there were four parts. The first is the time of entrusting the family business, which is not combined here;
The second is gathering the assembly to bear witness, which is also not combined here;
The third is clarifying the natural affinity between father and son, which is also not combined here;
Only the fourth, the actual entrustment of the family business, is combined.
The above is the correct entrustment, saying Now all the wealth and property I possess are yours. There is the main correspondence and the explanation of the correspondence.

Therefore we say we originally had no intention of seeking anything, but now the great treasure of the Dharma King has naturally arrived. The main text ends with the ninth point in the above story, where the children rejoice because they have obtained the family business. The above says, At that time the poor son, hearing these words from his father, was greatly delighted.

Repeating his thoughts, he spoke in verse. In the second part of the correct understanding and explanation, there were originally two sections. The first part, from and said to the Buddha to the 73 and a half lines of verse, is the correct understanding and explanation of the meaning of revealing the One after opening the Three. This understanding is not empty, and coming must have a reason.

Therefore, the second part, from the 13 lines of verse beginning with The World-Honored One's great kindness is difficult to repay, praises the Buddha's deep kindness and difficulty in repaying it, thus concluding the understanding and practice.
The previous explanation also says:

Each of the two sections is further divided into two. The correct understanding has two parts. The first is the prose, and from here down there are 73 and a half lines of verse, which is the second part, the verses.
But in the correct understanding in the prose there were originally three parts: first, a brief understanding;
second, before extensively understanding, first consulting the TathÄgata;
third, extensively understanding.
Now only the first brief understanding is versified, and the third extensive understanding is also versified, but the second consulting the TathÄgata is not versified.
Now, in these 73 and a half lines of verse, it is divided into two parts. First, there are two lines of verse that versify the first brief understanding above;
second, the remaining 71 and a half lines of verse versify the third extensive understanding above.
Moreover, in the brief understanding above there were originally two parts: first, a doctrinal explanation, and second, an explanatory illustration.
Now, the two lines are also divided into two parts. The first one and a half lines praise the doctrinal explanation, and the remaining half line praises the explanatory analogy.
But in the doctrinal explanation above, there were originally two sections. The first clarifies not seeking in the past, and the second clarifies obtaining by oneself in the present.
This one and a half lines of verse do not praise not seeking, but only praise obtaining by oneself.
The words hearing the unprecedented Dharma, deeply rejoicing and obtaining great good benefits above are praised.
Immeasurable precious treasures, obtained without seeking - this half verse praises the second explanatory analogy above.

In the explanatory analogy above, there were originally two sections. The first says the unsurpassed treasure aggregate, not sought as an analogy for not seeking in the past, and the second says obtained by oneself as an analogy for obtaining by oneself in the present.

Now this half-verse fully praises these two stages. The first line not seeking immeasurable treasures praises the above not seeking analogy, and the two characters self-obtained immediately praise the above today I have obtained analogy. But the words are still similar to the above, so it is known to be a praise.
It is like a young child... below this, there are 71 and a half lines, which is the second praise of the above third extensive understanding.
But in the above extensive understanding, there were originally two sections: the first is the analogy, and the second is the combination of the analogy.
Now, the 71 and a half lines of verse are also divided into two parts:
The first has 41 lines of verse praising the analogy, and the second has 30 and a half lines of verse praising the combination of the analogy.
In the above analogy, there were originally nine analogies. Now, in the 41 lines of verse, they are also divided into nine sections:
The first has 13 lines of verse, praising the first analogy of the father and son losing each other;
The second, from hired and wandered around to the end of the verse, has seven and a half lines, praising the second parable of the father and son seeing each other;
The third, from then ordered the messengers to the end of the verse, has three lines, praising the third parable of the father calling his son but not being able to reach him;
The fourth, from then used skillful means to the end of the verse, has three lines, praising the fourth parable of the father calling his son and being able to reach him;
The fifth, from the elder saw from the window to the end of the verse, has five and a half lines, praising the fifth parable of teaching the son to work;
The sixth, from showing him gold and silver to the end of the verse, has two lines, praising the sixth parable of entrusting the wealth;
The seventh, from the father knew that the son's mind had gradually become vast to the end of the verse, has half a line, praising the seventh parable of seeing the son's great ambition;
The eighth, from wanting to give him wealth to the end of the verse, has four and a half lines, praising the eighth parable of entrusting the family business;
The ninth, from the son thinking of his former poverty and low aspirations to the end of the verse, has two lines, praising the ninth parable of the son's joy.

translated: Now, the first seven and a half lines of verse are a further explanation of the first seven lines of verse, the next three lines explain the third, there are again three lines explaining the fourth, the next five and a half lines explain the fifth, two lines explain the sixth, half a line explains the seventh, the next four and a half lines explain the eighth, and two lines explain the ninth.
In the first part of the parable of the father and son being separated, there were originally four points:
First, the child left the father; second, the father searched for the child; third, the child returned and approached the father; fourth, the father's worry and concern deepened.
Now, the thirteen lines of verse also fully explain these four sections, but they are not in order and there are omissions.

Now, one and a half lines explain the first, next, six and a half lines explain the second, next, two and a half lines jump to explain the fourth, and next, two and a half lines follow to explain the third.
It is like a young child, ignorant and without discernment, one and a half lines first explain the first, the child leaving the father.
But above, the son leaving the father had two parts: first, saying he turned his back on his father and left, second, saying he returned to his own country.
Now this one and a half lines only praise the son turning his back on his father and leaving, not praising returning to his own country.
The father worried and thought - the six and a half lines below praise the father's search for his son in the above.

In the above, the father's search for his son originally had two steps: first, not finding his son, second, saying he did not abandon the great matter of the family business because of the suffering of losing one son. Now it is fully praised, saying the father worried and searched in the four directions - this half line praises not finding the son, above it says the father previously searched but did not find him.
Having searched and grown tired and below has six lines, which correctly praises the second part above, not abandoning the great matter of the family business.
The wealthy have such great power and influence - the two and a half lines below this verse supercedes the fourth verse, which further deepens the father's worry.
Above there were two parts: first, the suffering of losing a child; second, the joy of finding a child if one makes a wish.
Now, it does not chant the joy of finding a child if one makes a wish, it only chants the suffering of worrying about losing a child.
Above it says, The father always thinks of his son, separated from him for over fifty years.
At that time the poor son sought clothing and food - the two and a half lines below this verse pursue the third verse above, which states that the son was near his father.
Above, the son being near his father also has two parts: first, the conditions for being near his father; second, clearly stating being near his father.
Now, it is also fully chanted, with the first two lines chanting the conditions for being near his father, and the next half line clearly stating being near his father.

Approaching the father's circumstances means at that time, the poor son wandered through various villages and passed through towns and cities. From the five precepts to the five precepts, therefore it is said to go from village to village.
From the ten wholesome deeds to the ten wholesome deeds, therefore it is said to go from country to country.

Sometimes he obtained something, sometimes he obtained nothing means cultivating the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds in this life and receiving retribution in this body is called obtaining something.
Arousing a future retribution is called obtaining nothing.
Another explanation says:
Accomplishing karma that leads to a single lifetime is called obtaining something;
Not accomplishing it leads to a future retribution, called obtaining nothing.ğŸ”½Virtuous dharmas do not always suffice to support the body, therefore it is said to be emaciated.
Not only lacking virtuous dharmas, but also having the ninety-eight latent afflictions, therefore it is said to have sores and scabs on the body.

Gradually passing through, he arrived at the city where his father lived - this half verse clearly shows the son approaching his father above, which says he arrived at the city where his father was staying.
Hired as a laborer, he wandered and eventually arrived at his father's house - the seven and a half verses below praise the second part of the parable, the father and son seeing each other.
In the original parable, there were two sections: first, showing the son seeing the father; second, showing the father seeing the son.
Now, the first six and a half verses praise the first part, the son seeing the father.
At that time, the elder - one verse praises the second part, the father seeing the son.

In the original parable of the son seeing the father, there were originally four steps: first, the conditions for the son seeing the father; second, the place where the son saw the father; third, clearly showing the son seeing the father; fourth, the thought of fear and avoidance that arose.
